Scheme 1 Reaction scheme observed for butane dehydrogenation over prepared catalysts. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 (a) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm and (b) pore size distribution of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD spectra of support and prepared catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TPR patterns obtained for support, monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of Pd 3d region in a) Pd/Al b) Pd-Pt/Al and Pt 4f region in c) Pt/Al d) Pd-Pt/Al. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM images and particle size distribution of mono and bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 FTIR spectra of pyridine chemisorbed on support and catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NH3-TPD profiles for alumina support and prepared catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Catalytic performance of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts for butane dehydrogenation at different temperatures a) conversion b) product selectivity and c) total butene yield. Graphical abstract The alumina supported Pd-Pt based bimetallic catalysts were prepared by modified electroless deposition and evaluated for butane dehydrogenation. The bimetallic Pd-Pt catalysts exhibited superior performance compared to that of monometallic catalysts. The superior performance may be attributed to strong synergistic interaction between metals, stronger metal-support interaction and lower acidity. The higher activity of alloyed Pd-Pt metal resulted in higher conversion for bimetallic catalysts. The lower acidity resulted in higher butene selectivity and stability for bimetallic catalysts by minimizing cracking and secondary reactions. The co-deposited catalyst with more uniform distribution of Pd and Pt metals showed better performance than bimetallic catalysts prepared by sequential deposition. Co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed the highest butane conversion (50 %), butene yield (42 %) and stability. The reported yield is much higher than many reported values for Pt or Pd based catalysts. The co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst also exhibited better dehydrogenation performance in comparison to corresponding co-impregnated bimetallic catalyst. Keywords Modified electroless deposition Palladium-platinum bimetallic Butane dehydrogenation 1 Introduction The development of a more efficient catalyst for any process is always desirable. The performance of the catalyst may be improved in terms of activity and/or selectivity, and thereby increase the yield of desirable product. Increasing the stability of the catalysts is also a point of focus. Light olefins such as butenes are essential feedstock for the production of many valuable chemicals for downstream applications [1–6]. Recently, enhanced demand for butenes has caused their price to increase significantly [7,8]. Conventionally, the naphtha cracking process is used for production of butenes. It operates at high temperatures (>800 °C) and exhibits low alkene selectivity [1,9]. It is also associated with production of side products and coke formation. In many countries, with increase in shale gas production, naphtha is increasingly being replaced by ethane, the second major constituent of shale gas. This has also led to a decrease in the production of light olefins including butenes and butadiene [1]. Catalytic dehydrogenation of butane offers an attractive alternative route for production of butenes because it utilizes low-cost reactant, operates at lower temperature (<600 °C) and has significant selectivity for butenes [8,9]. The production of hydrogen as a co-product is another advantage [1,9]. However, the thermodynamic restrictions limit the conversion of butane to butenes due to the strong endothermic character of the reaction [4,5,10]. Moreover, deposition of coke at high temperatures causes deactivation while formation of lighter hydrocarbons by C-C cleavage results in decrease in selectivity of butene [6,8]. For dehydrogenation of butane, platinum is reported as the most efficient transition metal [9]. However, in the absence of second metal, it is reported to have low butene selectivity and also severely deactivates with time on stream [7]. Deactivation of the monometallic Pt catalyst is mainly caused by coke deposition while the low selectivity results from isomerization and cracking reactions [4,7]. Various supports such as Al2O3, MgAl2O4, zeolites, graphene, etc. have been reported for dehydrogenation reactions [2,5,7,11]. Also, many authors have investigated dehydrogenation of n-butane over Pt based catalysts in combination with second metal, such as Sn, In, Pb, Ag etc. deposited as bimetal or promoter [12–15]. These reported bimetallic catalysts were much more active than corresponding monometallic ones [16–20]. The addition of a second metal like tin, indium, gallium etc. to platinum catalyst [16,21,22] enhanced the selectivity towards the desired product with reduction in the coke formation [9,23–25]. Bocanegra et al. [12] showed that the addition of Pb to Pt catalyst in low amount (0.1 and 0.25 wt%) increased the butene yield to 30 % in comparison to that obtained for monometallic catalyst (∼16 %). The further addition of In to Pt-Pb catalyst also improved both selectivity and stability. Kurokawa et al. [13] reported that bimetallic Pt-Ag catalyst outperformed the monometallic Pt catalysts by improving the butane conversion from 28 to 50 %. The addition of Ag also enhanced the butene selectivity to 78 % from 62 %, obtained over monometallic Pt catalyst. Details of various reported studies on butane dehydrogenation over Pt based bimetallic catalysts are summarized in Table S1. Only few studies have been reported on use of Pd as hydrogenation/dehydrogenation catalysts [26,27]. The available data on dehydrogenation of butane over Pd based catalysts, is even more limited [28]. Supported Pd (0.34 wt%) catalyst employed to study propane dehydrogenation, exhibited similar deficiencies as reported for monometallic Pt catalysts. Modification with Sn as promoter (0.03 wt%), improved the dehydrogenation selectivity from 15 % to 33 %. The selectivity was further increased to 62 % with the increase in Sn content (0.08 wt%) [26]. For butane dehydrogenation, addition of Ga (0.72 wt%) had an overall positive effect on the catalytic activity of alumina supported Pd (0.66 wt%). The Ga modified Pd catalyst exhibited high butene selectivity (>95 %) in comparison to monometallic Pd (∼80 %) [28]. Hence, the Pd based bimetallic catalysts could also be of particular interest for dehydrogenation applications. Another advantage of palladium over platinum is relatively lower cost of precursor of the former. Another factor that has been reported to affect the performance of the catalyst is its preparation methodology [29,30]. It determines the distribution of metal clusters on the surface as well as their interaction with the support, which in turn affects the performance of the catalyst. Wetness impregnation (WI) is the most widely used preparation technique for supported metal catalysts [31,32]. However, it is associated with major limitations in terms of low dispersion and weak interaction of metal with the support. Hence, developing a preparation methodology, that enhances these properties, is expected to have a positive effect on performance of catalyst. This study used electroless deposition in modified form for preparation of supported catalysts encompassing the advantages of both conventional electroless plating and chemical reduction process to achieve high dispersion and metal-support interaction. Limited studies have reported electroless plating method for deposition of metals on supports using reducing agents [33,34]. The chemical reduction has also received attention due to the fact that the deposition of metal in reduced state eliminates the requirement of an energy intensive reduction process prior to catalysis application [35]. Further, the reduction of metal occurring on the surface of the support during deposition is expected to result in stronger interactions between the deposited metal and support [36]. The present work investigated the performance of bimetallic catalysts, prepared by modified electroless deposition, for n-butane dehydrogenation reaction and was compared with that of catalyst prepared by conventional wetness impregnation method. The bimetallic catalysts were prepared by depositing or impregnating equimolar amount of Pt and Pd on alumina as the support. The performance of the bimetallic catalysts was compared with that of corresponding monometallic catalysts in terms of activity, selectivity, yield and stability. This study also investigated the effect of preparation method in terms of sequence of metal addition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents used Hexachloroplatinic acid [H2PtCl6, Sigma-Aldrich] and palladium chloride [PdCl2, Sigma-Aldrich] were used as the metal precursors for Pt and Pd metals, respectively. Aluminium nitrate nona-hydrate [Al(NO3)3.9H2O, Merck] was used as the precursor for Al2O3 support. Ammonia solution [NH4OH, 25 mol% Merck] was used as the precipitating agent to carry out synthesis of aluminium hydroxide. Hydrazine hydrate, [N2H4.H2O, Merck] was used as the reducing agent. Hydrochloric acid [HCl, 37 % Merck] and ammonia solution were used to maintain a pH balance. All the chemicals were of analytical grade quality and used as received. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The aluminium oxide in form of powder was used as support. It was prepared by precipitation method using aluminium nitrate [Al(NO3)3.9H2O] as precursor. Details of preparation steps are presented in Fig. S1. All the catalysts were prepared with same total metal loading on molar basis. That is, all the catalysts contained 112 μ-moles of total metals per g of catalyst. For monometallic catalysts, this corresponded to 1.2 and 2.1 wt% of Pd and Pt metals, respectively. For bimetallic catalyst, each metal was 50 % of total metal loading on molar basis and this corresponded to 1.1 wt% loading for platinum and 0.6 wt% loading for palladium. The Pt or Pd precursor solutions were prepared by dissolving 116.5 mg of H2PtCl6 and 40 mg of PdCl2, respectively, in 40 mL of de-ionised water. Aqueous solution of hydrazine (reducing agent) was prepared by adding required volume of N2H4.H2O in distilled water. The stoichiometric equation for reduction of Pt or Pd using hydrazine is given as: (1) H 2 PtC l 6 + N 2 H 4 → P t 0 + N 2 + 6HCl (2) 2PdC l 2 + N 2 H 4 → 2P d 0 + N 2 + 4HCl Here, the molar ratio of reducing agent to metal precursor was maintained at 1:0.75 for PdCl2 and 1:1.5 for H2PtCl6. The molar ratio of reducing agent was in 50 % excess to that of metal precursor. The catalyst preparation by electroless deposition involved passing of the metal precursor and reducing agent solutions through the substrate sequentially. This facilitated deposition of metal on powder substrate in reduced state with minimal loss, gaining better control on interaction between metal precursor and reducing agent on support surface. This modified deposition method also helped in reducing bulk diffusion resistance. In a typical experiment, hydrazine solution (20 mL) was passed through 2 g of aluminium oxide support and filtered after 10 min using vacuum. Then, 20 mL of mono-metal precursor solution (Pd or Pt) was gradually poured through the filtered sample maintaining 10 min of interaction time. These two steps represented first cycle. In the second cycle, the filtrate of hydrazine solution (obtained after filtration of 1st cycle) was again passed through the support followed by filtrate of metal precursor solution maintaining an interaction time of 10 min. In the third and fourth cycle, fresh and filtrate solutions were passed, respectively, to get sufficient deposition of metal (Pt or Pd) on aluminium oxide. The resulting wet catalyst was then dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. For preparation of sequentially deposited Pd1Pt2/Al bimetallic catalyst, 20 mL of hydrazine solution was poured on alumina followed by Pd precursor solution (20 mL). In the second cycle, filtrate collected for both hydrazine and Pd metal precursor were again passed through the support. In the third cycle, second metal i.e. Pt precursor solution (20 mL) was gradually poured on alumina after pouring 20 mL of fresh N2H4 solution and in the fourth cycle again the hydrazine filtrate (obtained from 3rd cycle) was passed followed by Pt precursor filtrate solution. In this manner, Pd metal was loaded prior to Pt metal for Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst as shown in Fig. S2. Similarly, for Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst the sequence was reversed, in which Pt precursor solution was poured in 1st and 2nd cycles followed by addition of Pd solution in 3rd and 4th cycles. For co-deposition bimetallic Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, 20 mL of each Pd and Pt precursor solution was mixed and stirred for 5 min. The resulting 40 mL solution contained both the metal precursors in required quantity. In the first cycle, 20 mL fresh solution of hydrazine was poured and filtered after 10 min. It was followed by passage of 20 mL the Pd-Pt precursor solution prepared earlier. The respective filtrates of reducing agent and metal precursor solution were again passed through alumina in the second cycle. Similarly, third and fourth cycles were carried out by pouring of fresh and filtrate solutions, respectively, leading to co-deposition of Pd and Pt metal over the alumina support. The Pd-Pt bimetallic catalyst was also prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method with same metal loading for comparison purpose. In co-impregnation method, required amount of both Pd and Pt precursors were dissolved simultaneously in 6 mL of water corresponding to the pore volume of 2 g support. The metal precursor solution was then added to the support slowly and mixed thoroughly to make a uniform paste. The co-impregnated catalyst was then left at room temperature in air for 2 h and dried overnight in an oven at 110 °C. The dried sample was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the final catalyst. 2.3 Characterization The BET surface areas of the support and catalysts were obtained with nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements at liquid nitrogen temperature using Quanta chrome (Model: Autosorb iQ) surface area analyzer. The XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts were recorded on a diffractometer (Bruker D8 Instrument). The Pt and Pd loadings of catalysts were determined by Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (AAS) and further confirmed by energy dispersive X-rayspectroscopy (EDX) analysis using a EDX accessory attached to ZEISS FESEM (Model: SIGMA). The TPR experiments were carried out using a temperature program analyzer (Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720). The XPS analysis of the sample was done using PHI 5000 Versa Probe II, FEI Inc. The high-resolution TEM images of the metal particles were recorded by JEM 2100 (Make: JEOL). The analysis of all the TEM images was done using Image J. The acidic properties of catalysts were evaluated by FTIR spectroscopy (Perkin-Elmer 2000 FTIR spectrometer) using pyridine as probe molecule and by temperature-programmed desorption (Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720) using ammonia as the probe molecule. FTIR analysis of the samples using CO as the probe molecule was also carried out using Perkin-Elmer 2000 FTIR spectrometer. Further, details of the characterization analysis are included in Table S2. 2.4 Activity measurements The n-butane dehydrogenation was carried out in a fixed-bed continuous downflow reactor in the temperature range of 100–600 °C at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst (0.25 g) was mixed with 1 g of quartz powder and placed in the centre of the reactor. A thermocouple was placed in contact with the catalyst bed to measure the reaction temperature. The feed gas mixture, containing n-butane, H2 and N2 gases in the ratio of 1:3:6, was introduced to the reactor. The total flow rate was maintained at 100 mL min−1. The dehydrogenation activity of spent catalyst was investigated by repeating the reaction on same used catalyst. The effluent gas mixture was analyzed using an on-line Gas chromatograph (Nucon 5765) equipped with a Sebaconitrile column and a flame ionization detector (FID). Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas. The oven temperature was maintained at 40 °C while the injector and detector temperature were kept at 160 °C and 180 °C. The performance of the catalysts was evaluated in terms of conversion, selectivity, yield and percentage deactivation defined by following equations: (3) Butane conversion % = Moles of butan e in - Moles of butan e out Moles of butan e in × 100 (4) Selectivity of product A % = Moles of product A formed Total moles of products formed × 100 (5) Yield % = Moles of A product formed Moles of butane supplied × 100 (6) Percentage deactivation, D % = Conversioninitial - Conversionfinal ( t = 10h ) Conversioninitial × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The metal loadings (Pd and/or Pt) of the prepared catalysts were determined by doing AAS analysis of initial solution and final solution after deposition. On molar basis, the metal (Pt and Pd) loadings were obtained almost in the same range as targeted. The Pt content was in the range of 93–99 μmoles (∼1 wt%) while, Pd content was in the range of 85–99 μmoles (0.5−0.6 wt%) in bimetallic catalysts, as can be observed from Table 1 . The composition of the catalysts was also determined by EDX (Table S3) and was comparable to that obtained through AAS analysis. The corresponding EDX spectra for the catalysts are shown in Fig. S3. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of the aluminium oxide support showed Type IV nature and H2-type hysteresis loop. This corresponded to the mesoporous structure with interconnected pore network (Fig. S4a). The pore size distribution of the support was broad (2−18 nm) with an average pore size of 7 nm (Fig. S4b). The BET surface area of support was 184 m2 g−1 with total pore volume of 0.34 cm3 g−1. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions for all the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 a and b, respectively. All the catalysts exhibited Type IV isotherms with H2-type hysteresis loop, similar to that observed for the support. The BET surface area, pore volume and average pore size of the supported monometallic and bimetallic catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The surface area of all the catalysts was reduced in comparison to the support. This decrease can be attributed to the deposition of metal species within the pores [37,38]. The monometallic catalysts showed only a slight decrease in surface area with respect to the support. The Pt/Al catalyst exhibited a surface area of 181 m2 g−1 while it was 179 m2 g−1 for Pd/Al catalyst. The surface area of the sequentially deposited bimetallic catalysts dropped significantly, irrespective of the sequence of metal addition. The Pd1Pt2/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al showed surface areas of 149 and 147 m2 g−1, respectively. However, surface area of bimetallic catalyst prepared by co-deposition was 181 m2 g−1, not showing any significant decrease with respect to that of alumina support. The significant decrease in the BET surface areas of the sequentially deposited bimetallic samples with respect to alumina support suggested that sequential incorporation of metal resulted in higher pore blockage. Accordingly, the drop in pore volume was also significant for sequentially deposited catalysts as can be observed from Table 2. The pore volume of 0.343 cm3 g−1 observed for alumina support was reduced to 0.271 and 0.277 cm3 g−1 for sequentially deposited Pd1Pt2/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al catalysts, respectively. For co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, the pore volume was reduced to only 0.327 cm3 g−1. The average pore size was lower for all the catalysts (5.9−6 nm) with respect to that of the support (7 nm). No micropores were observed in any of the catalysts (Fig. 1b). The mesoporous character of the catalysts was expected to facilitate the transport of the reactants and products through the porous network [39]. From these results, it can be inferred that variation in deposition sequence of metal strongly affected the physical properties of the synthesized bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns for monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. For the alumina support, peaks due to γ-Al2O3 were obtained at 2θ values of 37.6° (111), 45.8° (200) and 66.8° (220) [JCPDS No 00-001-1303]. As can be observed from references, the peaks corresponding to Pd are expected at 40.15°, 46.15°, 68.19°, and the peaks for Pt at 39.7°, 47° and 68°. Thus, the position of the characteristic peaks corresponding to both the metals are close to that of γ-Al2O3. Hence, peaks due to metal crystallites would have been detected only if their intensity was high enough to supersede that of alumina peak. The comparison of the profiles of alumina support with that catalysts showed no significant variation in intensity of the corresponding peaks. These results suggested that the metal crystallites of sizes above 4 nm, if present on surface, were lower in concentration and hence difficult to detect by XRD. Lower loading of the metals might have also contributed to the non-detection of metal crystallites by XRD. It is reported that the XRD method is less sensitive for the detection of phases at low metal loading (<5 %) [40]. Hence, TEM analysis was used to determine the metal crystallite size distribution. The TEM analysis, as discussed later, indeed confirmed the presence of larger particles (> 4 nm) however, they constituted only smaller fractions (9–15 %) for all the catalysts. The TPR profiles of the catalysts with the de-convoluted peaks are shown in Fig. 3 . The presence of reduction peaks suggested that a fraction of the metals was in oxidized state. This might have resulted from incomplete reduction of the metals during deposition or by subsequent oxidation of metals on exposure to surroundings. The reduction peaks for the catalysts are summarized in Table S4. The monometallic catalyst, Pd/Al exhibited three peaks centered at 136 °C, 340 °C and 399 °C. The low temperature reduction peak at 136 °C corresponded to the reduction of the easily reducible palladium oxide crystallites having weak interaction with the support [41–43]. The broad peaks at 340 and 399 °C can be assigned to the reduction of relatively small and stable oxide species that are in a stronger interaction with the support [44,45]. Higher the reduction temperature, stronger is the interaction between metal clusters and support [46]. The reduction peaks were located at similar positions for Pt/Al catalyst, 194, 345 and 390 °C. The assignments of the peaks are same as that for Pd/Al corresponding to reduction of bulk or weakly interacting oxide at 194 °C and strongly interacting platinum oxide clusters with support at temperature >300 °C [25]. In the sequential bimetallic catalysts, the low temperature reduction peaks appeared to have shifted to further lower temperature compared to the both the monometallic catalysts. The Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst exhibited two reduction peaks at 100 and 170 °C while, Pd1Pt2/Al showed peak at 109 °C. This suggested weakening of metal-support interaction in bimetallic catalysts in comparison to monometallic catalysts, with formation of metal oxide clusters having stronger metal-metal interactions. For both the sequentially prepared catalysts, the reduction peaks at higher temperature also experienced a shift to lower value in bimetallic catalysts compared to that in monometallic catalysts. The effect was more visible in Pt1Pd2/Al. The results agreed with the existence of strong metal-metal interaction and weakening of support-metal interaction. The strong metal-metal interaction in bimetallic catalysts indicated formation of alloys between Pt and Pd, resulting in shift in their reduction behavior compared to that observed for pure form in monometallic catalysts. For the co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, similar strong metal-metal interaction was observed by shifting of reduction peaks. In co-deposited catalyst, appearance of a reduction peak at highest temperature of 432 °C suggested formation of nano-metal cluster existing in strongest interaction with the support. This peak was not observed for sequentially prepared bimetallic catalysts. The extent of reduction of co-deposited catalyst was similar to that of monometallic catalysts, however it was comparatively lower for sequentially deposited bimetallic samples. The TPR results suggested that the Pd-Pt interaction in bimetallic catalyst was stronger when metals were co-deposited. The core level XPS spectra of Pd (3d) and Pt (4f) region for monometallic and co-deposited bimetallic catalyst are shown in Fig. 4 . For Pd/Al catalyst, the Fig. 4a shows two peaks at 335.1 and 336.3 eV in Pd 3d5/2 region corresponding to the presence of Pd° and Pd2+ species, respectively [47,48]. The peaks were shifted to 335.0 (Pd°) and 336.4 eV (Pd2+) in the bimetallic Pd-Pt/Al catalyst as shown in Fig. 4b. As per Fig. 4c, the Pt/Al exhibited two peaks at 70.6 and 72.7 eV that corresponded to presence of metallic Pt° and oxidized Pt2+ species, respectively [45,49]. The binding energy values increased significantly from 70.6 to 71.1 eV and from 72.7 to 72.9 eV for Pt° and Pt2+ states, respectively, in bimetallic Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (Table 3 ). It has been reported that binding energy values are generated due to the ejection of photoelectrons from metal particles and depends on their size [50,51]. Smaller the metal particle, higher is the binding energy value. However, bimetallic Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited almost similar average particle size to that of mono metallic as established by TEM analysis. Hence, such a shift in binding energies observed for the metals in bimetallic catalyst compared to that of corresponding monometallic catalysts may be attributed to the modification in the electronic properties of Pd and Pt. These modifications might have caused by the electronic interactions between the metals resulting in the formation of Pd-Pt alloyed particles [52]. The significant 0.5 eV shift for Pt° in 4f region may be attributed to the transfer of electrons from Pd to Pt owing to higher electronegativity of the latter [53]. The Pd° accordingly underwent decrease in binding energy. Stronger metal-support interactions in bimetallic catalyst, as was also observed from TPR results, could be another reason for shift in BE values [45]. The binding energies, oxidation states and their relative contents for both metals are compiled in Table 3. The relative concentration ratio of Pd°/Pd2+ in Pd/Al and Pd-Pt/Al were 70/30 and 52/48, respectively. The ratio of Pt°/Pt+2 were found to be 64/36 and 53/47 for Pt/Al and Pd-Pt/Al catalysts, respectively. The oxidized state might have resulted either from incomplete reduction during deposition or partial oxidation by atmospheric oxygen during storage as stated earlier. Interestingly, the co-deposited bimetallic catalyst displayed presence of almost equal amount of metallic and oxidized states for both the metals. About 52–53 % of both the metals was observed to be in zero oxidation state in the co-deposited catalyst. The supported metal sites were also analyzed by FTIR using CO as the probe molecule for monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. The corresponding spectra in the range of 2250−1800 cm−1 are included in supplementary as Fig. S6. The IR spectrum of both the monometallic Pd and Pt catalyst showed a CO vibrational band centered at 2084 cm−1 corresponding to CO bounded linearly to the metal sites [54,55]. These metal sites are reported to be active for dehydrogenation [56]. Two peaks were observed at 2088 and 2078 cm−1 for CO adsorbed to metal sites in alloyed clusters in Pd-Pt/Al bimetallic catalyst. The shift to lower frequency may be assigned to CO coordinated to electron rich platinum in alloyed cluster. It is reported in literature that strengthening of carbon-metal interaction weakens the carbon–oxygen bond thereby, resulting in shift of the peak to lower frequency. It has been reported in several studies that alloying with a second metal lowered the vibration frequency of CO adsorbed on alloyed Pt sites [57]. The peak at higher frequency for bimetallic catalysts may be assigned to weakening of CO interaction with alloyed Pd sites due to shift of its electron to Pt and thereby strengthening the CO interaction [55]. Thus, the FTIR analysis of adsorbed CO established the change in electronic structure of metals in bimetallic catalyst compared to that in respective monometallic catalysts. The formation of Pd-Pt alloy was thus confirmed in the bimetallic catalyst [58]. The TEM images of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The average size of the metal clusters ranged from 3 to 5 nm. The corresponding standard deviations are included in Table S5 in supplementary and the range agreed with that reported in literature [59]. The monometallic Pd/Al and Pt/Al catalysts exhibited average metal cluster sizes of 4.6 nm and 3.4 nm, respectively. Since the reduction potential of Pt is higher, Pt is expected to be reduced and deposited on the surface at a faster rate compared to that of Pd. This might have generated higher number of nucleation sites on surface in case of Pt deposition. Consequently, slightly lower growth of metal clusters was observed during deposition of Pt compared to that for Pd deposition. For bimetallic catalysts, where deposition of Pt was carried out prior to Pd as in Pt1Pd2/Al, the average cluster size was lower (3.8 nm) compared to that in Pd1Pt2/Al (4.3 nm). The synergistic effect of Pd-Pt in co-deposited catalysts may have resulted to a lowest average cluster size of 3.6 nm. The formation of lowest supported metal clusters on surface of the co-deposited catalyst was also confirmed by TPR profile which showed presence of reduction peak at highest temperature. The metallic dispersion (D%) over the monometallic as well as the bimetallic catalysts was calculated using the following equation [60]: (7) D = 1.13 d where, d is the average particle size of deposited metals in nm as determined from TEM analysis. The dispersion values obtained for Pd/Al, Pt/Al, Pd1Pt2/Al, Pd-Pt/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al were 24.5, 33.2, 26, 31.4 and 29.4 %, respectively. Dispersion of few samples was also determined by CO-chemisorption method. The values agreed closely to the corresponding values obtained from TEM analysis. For example, the dispersion values obtained for Pd/Al, Pt/Al and Pd-Pt/Al were 21, 29 and 28.7 %, respectively. These dispersion calculations were based on total metal loadings for all the catalysts. Dawody et al. [61] also reported close dispersion values when determined both by TEM and CO chemisorption analysis. The structures of the bimetallic catalyst were also analyzed using SAED (Selected Area Electron Diffraction) patterns obtained during HRTEM analysis as shown in Fig. S7. The ring identification was done through CrysT Box software. The diffraction pattern obtained for the catalysts provided information on the perpendicular distance between adjacent lattice planes (i.e. d-spacing) of Pt and Pd. The ring patterns obtained from the SAED analysis of Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst showed the presence of Pt predominantly in section of the clusters with Pd in the outer zone. The presence of inner platinum was also observed for Pd-Pt/Al, where both the metals were co-deposited. As suggested earlier, the higher reduction rate of platinum might have resulted in its preferential deposition. Even for the Pd1Pt2/Al, where Pd was deposited prior to Pt, the appearance of some Pt in inner core suggested galvanic displacement of some of the initially deposited Pd by Pt. The higher reduction potential of Pt compared to that of Pd might have facilitated the galvanic displacement of later, when the sample was exposed to solution of Pt precursor. Pt was also observed in the exterior for Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst. In Pd-Pt/Al co-deposited catalyst, more uniform distribution of Pd and Pt was observed. The surface acidity was determined from IR spectra (Fig. 6 ) of the support and catalysts using pyridine as probe molecule. For alumina support, four peaks were observed at 1450, 1490, 1620 and 1637 cm−1. The peaks at 1450 and 1620 cm−1 may be assigned to pyridine adsorbed to Lewis acid sites [62,63]. In several studies, the peaks observed in the range of 1635−1640 cm−1 have been assigned to interaction of pyridine with Bronsted acid sites [64,65]. Accordingly, the peak at 1637 cm−1 observed for alumina was assigned to Bronsted acid sites. Analysis of sample at room temperature condition may had given rise to considerable amount of surface hydroxyl groups contributing to Bronsted acidity [62]. The peak appearing at 1490 cm−1 was associated with both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites [66,67]. The intensity of these peaks was highest for alumina and decreased for catalysts after addition of metals. The decrease in the acidity for the metal catalysts may be attributed to the coverage or interactions of the support acidic sites with deposited metals. The acidity of Pt/Al was observed to be higher than that of Pd/Al as intensity of Lewis acid sites was lower and that of Bronsted acid sites were negligible for later. The disappearance of Bronsted acid sites for Pd/Al catalyst suggested that on deposition Pd preferentially interacted with these acidic sites involving OH groups. The higher interaction might have been caused by higher affinity of Pd for hydrogen thereby neutralizing all the Bronsted sites on the support surface. Pt also exhibited same tendency to interact with Bronsted sites OH but to lower extent, thus loss in Bronsted acid sites on Pt/Al catalyst was less. The decrease in intensity for Lewis acid sites can also be explained based on interaction of metals with these sites. These metals have tendency to interact with Lewis sites and get partially oxidized. As the oxidation potential of Pd is higher than that of Pt, interaction of Pd with Lewis sites was greater. Hence, less availability of Lewis sites on Pd/Al catalyst resulted in lower intensity for peak of adsorbed pyridine compared to that observed for Pt/Al catalyst. For metal doped samples, pyridine can also interact with the metals sites. The metal crystallites themselves can act as Lewis acids sites [59,68]. Since Pt has higher reduction potential compared to that of Pd, its ability to interact with electron lone pair of pyridine was higher. As a result, intensity of peak at 1450 cm−1 was higher for Pt/Al catalyst compared to that of Pd/Al. For bimetallic catalysts, the intensity of peaks with respect to support or monometallic catalysts depended of the sequence of metal deposition. The Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst showed acidic behavior more like Pt/Al monometallic catalyst while Pt1Pd2/Al showed similar behavior with that of Pd/Al catalyst. This behavior can be explained based on distribution of Pd and Pt in metal clusters for bimetallic catalysts as discussed earlier. The Pd1Pt2/Al with presence of more Pt in outer zone of cluster showed behavior similar to Pt/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al with more Pd in exterior part of cluster had acidic characteristic similar to that of Pd/Al catalyst. The co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst having more uniform metal distribution showed intermediate behavior. The intensity of both the Lewis acid and Bronsted acid sites among bimetallic catalysts decreased in the following order: Pd1Pt2/Al > Pd-Pt/Al > Pt1Pd2/Al. The peak at 1490 cm−1 was also observed for all the catalysts and the intensity of this peak did not change significantly among the samples. Fig. 7 compares the NH3-TPD profiles of the support and the catalysts. The corresponding total acidity in terms of ammonia uptake in mmol g−1 is summarized in Table 4 . All the NH3-TPD profiles were de-convoluted using Gaussian function to obtain the distribution of acidic strength of the samples. All the samples exhibited three types of peaks. The first peak (I) at 120−150 °C corresponded to weak acidic sites, the second peak (II) at 200−250 °C can be attributed to acidic sites of medium strength, and the third peak (III) at 350−400 °C can be considered as strong acidic sites [3]. The alumina support revealed the dominance of strong acidic sites with complete absence of weaker acidic sites. As shown in Table 4, the total acidity for the alumina support was highest with an ammonia uptake of 8.83 mmol g−1. Both the monometallic catalysts exhibited lower acidity than alumina support. The acidity of Pd/Al was lower (5.24 mmol NH3 g−1) compared to that of Pt/Al catalyst (7.11 mmol NH3 g−1). The presence of all three types of acidic sites was observed in both the monometallic catalysts; Pt/Al showed slightly higher content of weaker sites while Pd/Al showed slightly higher content of sites of medium strength. Both showed similar quantity of stronger acidic sites. The result indicated that the incorporation of metals to the support decreased the acidic sites, which is well in agreement with the results obtained from FTIR analysis of adsorbed pyridine. All the bimetallic catalysts also exhibited lower acidity compared to alumina support but higher than that of monometallic catalysts. Higher acidity in bimetallic catalysts may be a combined effect of presence of both the metals. The total acidity and relative distribution of acidic sites for bimetallic catalysts depended on the metal deposition sequence. The order of the total acidity (NH3 uptakes) was Pd1Pt2/Al > Pd-Pt/Al > Pt1Pd2/Al, same as was observed from pyridine adsorption study. Accordingly, Pd1Pt2/Al exhibited highest fraction of medium and strong acid sites followed by Pd-Pt/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al. The Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst, with presence more Pt in outer zone of metal clusters as discussed earlier, retained the highest acidity in comparison to other two bimetallic catalysts while in Pt1Pd2/Al with more Pd in outer section of metal clusters showed lowest acidity among bimetallic catalyst. The overall order of acidity in terms of total ammonia uptake was Alumina > Pd1Pt2/Al > Pd-Pt/Al > Pt/Al > Pt1Pd2/Al > Pd/Al. The acidity pattern obtained correlates well with the results of FTIR analysis of adsorbed pyridine. 3.2 Dehydrogenation activity tests Fig. 8 a illustrates the n-butane conversion in the temperature range of 100−600 °C for catalysts synthesized using electroless deposition. The conversion of n-butane steadily increased with increase in the reaction temperature for all the catalysts. At 100 °C, the monometallic Pd and Pt catalysts did not show any conversion. At 200 °C, the conversion was detected for both the monometallic catalysts but, conversion of Pt/Al was higher than that of Pd/Al. This trend was observed up to temperature of 500 °C. As the temperature increased, difference in activity was decreased. At 550 °C, both the monometallic catalysts showed similar activity. Thereafter, the activity of Pt/Al started to decrease but that of Pd/Al continued to increase. The conversion was reduced from 18.4 % at 550 °C to 16.3 % at 600 °C for Pt/Al catalyst. In case of Pd/Al, the conversion of 17.9 % at 550 °C increased to 21.1 % at 600 °C. The results showed that the Pd/Al catalyst was more active at higher temperatures. All the bimetallic catalysts showed better dehydrogenation activity in comparison to the monometallic catalysts. The dehydrogenation was observed even at 100 °C for bimetallic catalysts. The conversion was about 6–8 % at 100 °C, which gradually increased with the increasing temperature. In the temperature range of 100−300 °C, the Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst, with more Pt in outer regions of metal clusters, showed highest activity while Pt1Pd2/Al with more Pd in outer zone showed the lowest activity. From 400 °C onwards, the activity of the Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst was quite lower compared to other two bimetallic catalysts, though the conversion still increased with temperature and was higher than both the monometallic catalysts. Between 100−300 °C, the co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed intermediate activity compared to other two sequentially deposited bimetallic catalysts. However, beyond 400 °C the activity of co-deposited catalyst was highest closely followed by that of Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst. At higher temperature range of 400−600 °C the activity of bimetallic catalysts was much higher compared to monometallic catalysts and the order obtained was Pd-Pt/Al > Pt1Pd2/Al > Pd1Pt2/Al > Pd/Al > Pt/Al. The conversions of the catalysts at 550 °C are summarized in Table 5 . The highest conversion was obtained for Pd-Pt/Al (48.8 %) closely followed by the Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst (48.5 %) at 550 °C. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the catalysts were determined based on the total metal loading. Bimetallic catalysts exhibited higher TOFs than monometallic catalysts with Pd-Pt/Al showing highest TOF of 1.18 s−1 followed by Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst (1.15 s-1). Both the monometallic catalysts exhibited similar TOFs of about 0.43 s−1 at 550 °C. The higher activity of bimetallic catalysts may be attributed to higher synergy between two deposited metals. The alloy formation was confirmed by TPR and XPS studies. Since, the dispersion of metallic cluster in bimetallic catalyst was almost in similar range to that of monometallic catalysts, the higher activity of the bimetallic catalysts must have resulted from higher activity of the alloys present. The butenes along with C1-C3 hydrocarbons were the main products obtained during dehydrogenation of butane. The C1–C3 compounds included methane, ethane, ethylene, propane, and propylene. Both 1-butene and 2-butene were produced, while formation of butadiene was not observed. All the butene isomers were observed in the products. No higher hydrocarbons beyond butenes were detected. The overall selectivity trends for products in the temperature range of 500−600 °C for all the catalysts are shown in Fig. 8b. The selectivity towards cracked products increased slowly with rising temperature up to 550 °C, but thereafter the increase was drastic at 600 °C as can be observed from the figure. The selectivity towards butenes decreased from 85.6 to 82.3 % for Pt/Al catalyst on increasing the temperature from 500 to 550 °C, while Pd/Al exhibited >90 % selectivity in the similar temperature range. On increasing the temperature to 600 °C, butene selectivity dropped for both catalysts to ∼63−65 % due to increase in formation products by C-C cleavage. The results are in agreement with studies that observed enhanced cracking reactions at higher process temperature lowering the selectivity of butene [28]. The product distributions at 550 °C for all catalysts are given in Table 5. Among monometallic catalysts, Pt/Al had slightly higher selectivity for cracked C1-C3 products (14–18 %) compared to that shown by Pd/Al catalyst (about 9 %). At the reaction temperature of 550 °C, Pt/Al showed higher selectivity for 1-butene, while Pd/Al showed higher selectivity for 2-butenes. Pt/Al catalyst showed 22.7 % and 19.6 % selectivity for 1-butene and isobutene, respectively, and the corresponding values were 19.6 and 13.9 % for Pd/Al. The Pd/Al catalyst exhibited 57 % selectivity for 2 butenes (33 % trans-2-butene and 24 % cis-2-butene) compared to 40 % shown by Pt/Al catalyst (22 % trans-2-butene and 18 % cis-2-butene). In the temperature range of 500−525 °C, the bimetallic catalysts Pd-Pt/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al exhibited higher selectivity towards butenes in comparison to monometallic Pt/Al, while it was more or less similar to that of Pd/Al catalyst. The bimetallic Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst exhibited lowest selectivity towards butenes in the same range. In contrast to monometallic catalysts, bimetallic catalysts retained higher butene selectivity (70–76 %) even on raising the temperature to 600 °C. The selectivity pattern for bimetallic catalysts depended on the metal deposition sequence. The bimetallic catalyst, Pd1Pt2/Al showed highest selectivity of 19.7 % towards C1-C3 products, followed by co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al (14.5 %). The lowest selectivity of 12.4 % towards C1-C3 products was observed for Pt1Pd2/Al. Accordingly, at 550 °C, the total selectivity towards butene formation was highest for Pt1Pd2/Al (87.6 %) followed by that of Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (85.5 %), while it was lowest for Pd1Pt2/Al, 71.5 %. The lowest butene selectivity of Pd1Pt2/Al agreed with the fact that it had more Pt in outer zone of metal cluster and as noted earlier Pt/Al catalyst showed lower selectivity for butene. The higher selectivity of butene for Pt1Pd2/Al similarly can be explained by presence of higher percentage of Pd in outer shells of the metals clusters. Thus, the bimetallic catalyst Pd1Pt2/Al had similar product distribution that of Pt/Al while Pt1Pd2/Al showed similar selectivity trend as Pd/Al. The Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed intermediate behavior between the two catalysts. The higher surface acidity in Pt/Al and Pd1Pt2/Al catalysts, as apparent from the TPD and FTIR analysis, may have led to formation of more cracked products. At higher temperature, more cracking resulted in blocking of the active sites and hence reduction in activity was observed for these catalysts. The Pd/Al and Pt1Pd2/Al catalysts that exhibited least acidity showed lowest selectivity towards cracked products and highest selectivity to butenes. Fig. 8c shows the total butene yield over the catalysts in the temperature range of 500−600 °C. The yield was calculated from conversion and corresponding selectivity as given in Eq. (4) in Section 2.4. Compared to monometallic catalysts, the yield of butenes was significantly higher for the bimetallic catalysts. The higher yield resulted from higher conversion as well as higher selectivity observed for bimetallic catalysts. The maximum butene yields were obtained at a reaction temperature of 525−550 °C. Among the bimetallic catalysts, the co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al exhibited highest yield (44 %) for butenes followed by sequentially deposited Pt1Pd2/Al catalyst (42.4 %). The yield of Pd1Pt2/Al (28 %) was lowest among the bimetallic catalysts. The comparison of conversion and yield data of present catalysts with that of reported Pt based catalysts (Table S1) shows that the values were better for co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst at a similar temperature range. Fig. 9 shows the change in conversion of butane at 550 °C with time on stream for 10 h. The bimetallic catalysts were more stable compared to monometallic catalysts with time on stream. The catalytic activity of Pd-Pt/Al remained highest for entire range of time studied, closely followed by Pt1Pd2/Al. The Pd1Pt2/Al catalyst experienced a more severe deactivation after 2 h of study but gradually became stable in the later stage. On the other hand, both the monometallic catalysts, Pd/Al and Pt/Al, suffered continuous deactivation and lost their activity significantly by the end of study after 10 h. The initial conversions of Pt/Al, Pd/Al, Pd1Pt2/Al, Pt1Pd2/Al and Pd-Pt/Al catalysts were 19.7, 20.3, 40.1, 44 and 47 %, which after 10 h decreased to 3.8, 4.8, 29.9, 37.1 and 39.7 % respectively. The order of deactivation of the catalysts calculated (using the Eq. (6) given in Section 2.4) after 10 h of reaction time was as follows: Pd-Pt/Al (15 %) < Pt1Pd2/Al (16 %) < Pd1Pt2/Al (25 %) < Pd/Al (76 %) < Pt/Al (81 %). The lower deactivation for the bimetallic catalysts might have resulted from lower selectivity towards cracked products. Based on the catalytic performance as discussed above, a mechanistic approach is shown in Scheme 1 . The scheme shows that the butane molecules get adsorbed on metal sites and undergoes CH activation followed by hydrogen extraction to form butene. These butenes may get desorbed or undergo further secondary reactions to form lower hydrocarbons by CC bond activation. The reaction results suggested that the butane dehydrogenation on prepared catalysts involved both primary and secondary reactions depending on the reaction conditions. The comparison of the conversion data of monometallic Pt/Al and Pd/Al suggested that at lower temperature Pt/Al was more active than that of Pd/Al. The Pd/Al showed similar or higher activity only at higher temperature beyond 450 °C. This suggested that the energy barrier for dehydrogenation was higher on Pd sites compared to that on Pt sites. The higher energy barrier for Pd sites might have resulted from the lower interaction tendency of Pd towards hydrocarbons [69]. Hence, for the co-deposited alloyed bimetallic catalyst with equal probability of exposure of Pd and Pt sites, the alkane is expected to interact preferentially with the Pt sites compared to that with Pd sites. As the temperature increased both platinum and palladium sites in alloyed metal contributed to the dehydrogenation reaction increasing the total activity significantly at higher temperature, as observed. At lower temperature, mainly butenes were formed with negligible formation of C1-C3 hydrocarbons. This suggested absence of any secondary reactions of butene or C-C hydrogenolysis of butane at this low temperature condition. At higher temperature, appearance of lower hydrocarbons suggested contribution of these reactions. The higher activation energy of C-C cleavage compared to C-H activation agreed with this observations [70]. At higher temperature, simultaneous rupture of C-C bonds on the stronger support acidic sites may have also contributed significantly towards formation of lighter hydrocarbons/cracked products [71,72]. The products of cracking reactions can further undergo oligomerization or polymerization leading to coke formation. The analysis of spent catalyst, as discussed later, showed negligible deposition of coke on catalyst surface under used reaction conditions. This suggested absence of coke generating reactions on the catalyst surface. This also agreed with the high selectivity observed for butene over co-deposited bimetallic catalyst. Since there was no major difference in metal size distribution and thereby metal dispersion between bimetallic and monometallic catalysts hence, exposed support acidic sites can be assumed to be similar in all the catalysts. Therefore, the contribution of these support acidic sites to C-C cleavage reactions can be expected to be similar. The difference in selectivity pattern of the bimetallic and monometallic catalysts therefore might have resulted due to modification of electronic structure of alloyed metals in the former. The increase in electron density on Pt sites in alloyed metal clusters in bimetallic catalyst (as observed from XPS studies) allowed the product butene to desorb from the active sites more easily as compared to the monometallic metal sites. Faster butene desorption may be attributed to repulsive interaction between CC and e-rich Pt sites [69]. Faster desorption of product butene thereby generated vacant active metal sites, ready for further butane adsorption and subsequent dehydrogenation. This contributed to higher butane conversion over alloyed metal sites on bimetallic catalysts. The faster desorption also prevented butenes from undergoing deep dehydrogenation on alloyed metal sites facilitating inhibition of undesired secondary reactions. Consequently, butene selectivity and catalytic stability were improved as observed [72,73]. The heat of adsorption for alkenes is reported to be lowered by alloyed formations [53]. The presence of Pd as the other metal in alloyed cluster which had inherently lower interaction tendency with hydrocarbons, as discussed above, only further improved the selectivity. The lower probability of formation C-C cleavage products might have inhibited the occurrence of coke generating reactions thereby increasing the stability of the bimetallic catalysts. 3.3 Analysis of spent catalyst The detailed characterization studies of the spent Pd-Pt/Al catalyst were done and the results were compared with that of the fresh catalyst to understand effect of reaction conditions on the physicochemical properties of the catalyst. The Pd-Pt/Al was selected as it gave the best performance among the studied catalysts. The spent catalyst was subjected to surface area and pore analysis, TGA, XPS, and TEM. The dehydrogenation was also carried out over spent catalyst. All the results are shown in Fig. 10 . The Fig. 10a compares the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of spent and fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. No significant change in nature of isotherm was observed for spent Pd-Pt/Al catalyst compared to that of the fresh one. Only a slight decrease in volume of adsorbed nitrogen was observed for the spent catalyst. Accordingly, the corresponding surface area of Pd-Pt/Al_spent was marginally lowered to 175 m2 g−1 compared to 181 m2 g−1 for the fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (Table S5). The comparison of pore size distribution in Fig. 10a shows that for Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst, the distribution was slightly broadened (2−11 nm) as compared to that of fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (3−8 nm). The corresponding average pore size and pore volume for Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst were also slightly reduced as illustrated in Table S6. The slight decrease in surface area, pore volume and average pore size for Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst may be attributed to coke deposition or moderation of catalyst during reaction. However, only marginal decrease in the physical properties also suggested extent of carbon deposition or moderation to be very low. The weight analysis of catalyst before and after reaction confirmed the coke deposition to be negligible, less than 0.5 wt.%. The result was also confirmed by TGA analysis in flow of air that showed coke deposition to be less than 1 wt.%. This low coke deposition may be accounted by two reasons. First is the presence of hydrogen in feed that suppressed the formation coke precursors. Secondly, it was observed and discussed in detail in earlier section how the alloyed metal sites in co-deposited bimetallic catalyst prevented secondary reactions, minimizing the formation of coke precursors. The XPS analysis was carried out for Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst to investigate the modification in its electronic structure, if any, due to exposure to reaction conditions. The corresponding profiles are included in Fig. 10c. It was observed that the intensity of Pt 4f peak was reduced in spent catalyst in comparison to that in the fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. The peaks were observed at 71.1 eV (for Pt°), 72.9 eV (for Pt2+), 335.0 eV (for Pd°) and 336.4 eV (for Pd2+) in the fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. The corresponding peaks in monometallic catalysts were observed at 70.6 (Pt°), 72.7 eV (Pt2+), 335.1 (Pd°) and 336.3 eV (Pd2+), as already has been discussed in details in earlier section. The XPS profiles of the spent Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed the peak positions of same metallic and oxidized species at 70.8 eV (Pt°), 72.7 (for Pt2+), 335.2 eV (Pd°), and 336.5 (for Pd2+), respectively. The comparison of binding energies of monometallic, fresh bimetallic and spent bimetallic suggested that there was slight redistribution of the electronic structure after the exposure of catalyst to reaction conditions. The lowering of electron density on alloyed Pt-sites for spent bimetallic catalysts compared to that in fresh bimetallic catalyst suggested some adverse effect on Pd-Pt interaction on the support by modification of structure during reaction. The ratio of Pd°/Pd2+ and Pt°/Pt+2 in Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst were 51/49 and 47/53, respectively. These values are mostly similar to that observed for fresh catalyst (Table 3). TEM images of spent Pd-Pt/Al catalyst are illustrated in Fig. 10d. The average metal size increased slightly from 3.6 nm for fresh Pd-Pt/Al to 4 nm for Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst. The corresponding dispersion value decreased to 28.2 % for spent catalyst from 31.4 % obtained for fresh catalyst. The high resolution TEM images of Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst showed some distinct morphology that was not observed in fresh catalyst (Fig. 10d). This new disordered morphology may be assigned to the presence of coke deposits on catalyst surface [73]. After carrying out the dehydrogenation reaction on fresh Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, it was reused. The butane dehydrogenation was repeated on the Pd-Pt/Al_spent catalyst under similar conditions. The corresponding butane conversion and total butene selectivity for both the runs are compared in Fig. 10e. Run 1 represents reaction over fresh catalyst while, Run 2 was carried out over spent catalyst. It was observed that the catalytic activity obtained in Run 2 using the spent catalyst was quite close to that obtained using fresh catalyst (Run 1). The highest butane conversion of 48.8 % at 550 °C on fresh catalyst was decreased to 45.2 % for spent catalyst at same temperature. The corresponding decrease in total butene selectivity and yield, respectively, at 550 °C were also marginal: Run 1 (85.5 %, 41.7 %) and Run 2 (82.4 %, 37.2 %). Thus, decrease in dehydrogenation performance, in terms of activity, selectivity and yield, was not significant for spent catalyst. The dehydrogenation results agreed with the characterization study of spent catalyst which showed only marginal modification in physical and electronic structure along with very minor coke deposition. Only minor changes in physical and electronic structure of alloyed metal sites in spent catalyst, as observed from TEM and XPS data respectively, suggest that alloyed nano-metals were mostly stable in the reaction condition used. 3.4 Comparison with co-impregnated catalyst The physicochemical properties as well as the performance for butane dehydrogenation for co-deposited catalyst prepared by electroless deposition method was compared with that of the corresponding bimetallic WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst prepared by wetness co-impregnation. The metal loading of co-impregnated catalyst was kept similar as that of prepared by co-deposition. The physical properties of WI_Pd-Pt/Al have been compared with that of Pd-Pt/Al and shown in Fig. S8–S11. The composition analysis by EDS confirmed that the metal loading of co-impregnated catalyst was comparable to that of the co-deposited catalyst as shown in Table S6. The EDS mapping results shown in Fig. S8 revealed that the metal particles were clustered and unevenly distributed over the support in co-impregnated WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst while metals were more uniformly dispersed in the Pd-Pt/Al catalyst prepared by electroless deposition. The WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited a lower surface area of 154 m2 g−1 with a slight reduction in pore volume and pore size in comparison to that of Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (Table S7). The crystal structure of co-impregnated catalysts as obtained by XRD analysis showed similar profiles to that of co-deposited catalyst, Fig. S9b. The TPR profiles of both the co-impregnated and co-deposited catalysts are shown in Fig. S9c. The co-impregnated bimetallic catalyst, WI_Pd-Pt/Al exhibited reduction peak centered at 90 °C, lower than that observed for Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. The comparatively higher intensity of reduction peak at lower temperature in co-impregnated catalyst suggested presence of higher quantity of large size oxidized metal clusters that are in weak interaction with the support and thus more easily reducible. The core level XPS spectra in Fig. S9d showed Pd 3d5/2 and Pt 4f7/2 region for WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. The peaks at 334.6 and 336 eV due to metallic Pd° and oxidized Pd2+ were detected. A negative shift in BE values for WI_Pd-Pt/Al compared to that observed for Pd-Pt/Al may have resulted due to the presence of larger size of metal clusters in co-impregnated catalyst as was observed from TPR analysis and also confirmed from TEM image. From the TEM image, it was observed that metal clusters were densely distributed in impregnated catalyst and corresponding average size was 10 nm (Fig. S10), which was much higher compared to that of Pd-Pt/Al catalyst (3.6 nm). The corresponding dispersion for co-impregnated catalyst was only 11.3 %, much lower than 31.3 % for the co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. Similar shift in BE values was also observed in Pt 4f region, 70.9 and 72.3 eV, that are attributed to metallic Pt° and Pt2+ states. Also, in WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, the ratio of Pd2+/Pd° and Pt2+/Pt° was 58/42 and 84/16, respectively, higher with respect to that observed to the Pd-Pt/Al bimetallic catalyst (48/52 and 47/53) suggesting presence of metals mainly in oxidized state in former. This might have been caused by absence of any reducing agent during preparation of co-impregnated catalyst. The surface acidity of the co-impregnated bimetallic catalyst, as observed from FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. S11), was higher compared to that of Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. This was confirmed from higher intensity of the peaks for former. The higher acidity of impregnated catalyst may be attributed to its lower dispersion and large cluster size of metals thereby, exposing stronger acidic sites on the support surface. Fig. 11 a compares the butane conversion obtained over both the catalysts in the temperature range of 100–600 °C. At all temperatures, the co-deposited catalysts showed higher activity compared to that of co-impregnated catalyst. At lower temperature, below 300 °C, the WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst did not show any conversion. The WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited conversion of 29.9 % at 600 °C which is considerably lower than that observed for Pd-Pt/Al catalyst, 48.8 %. Table 6 compares the selectivity towards the products at 550 °C for both the catalysts. The selectivity towards undesired cracking products was higher for the catalyst prepared by co-impregnation method. The WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited about 45 % selectivity towards cracked products with 55 % butene selectivity. For catalyst synthesized using co-deposition, the selectivity towards butenes was much higher (85 %). Both the catalysts exhibited higher selectivity towards the formation of trans-2-butene followed by cis-2-butene. The product yield obtained at 550 °C by these two catalysts is presented in Fig. 11b. The Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited superior butene yield (41.7 %) compared to that by WI_Pd-Pt/Al, giving only 15.8 % yield. The lower yield of butene for co-impregnated catalyst resulted due to low conversion and low butene selectivity. Fig. 11c compares the conversion of butane over Pd-Pt/Al and WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalysts at 550 °C as function of time on stream for a period of 10 h. The WI_Pd-Pt/Al catalyst experienced a severe deactivation during the process and thereby was highly unstable in comparison to the Pd-Pt/Al catalyst. The catalyst prepared by co-deposition method showed an initial conversion of 49.1 %, which reduced to 39.7 % after 10 h exhibiting only 19 % deactivation. While the initial conversion of 29 % obtained for WI_Pd-Pt/Al decreased to 10 % after 10 h, thus exhibiting approximately 65 % deactivation over the same period of time. Such a deactivation might have been caused by higher production of cracking products over impregnation catalyst where, the activity was suppressed due to the deposition of coke on catalyst surface. Thus, this study clearly suggested that catalyst preparation method had a significant effect on catalyst performance and stability the catalyst prepared by co-deposition method was superior. 4 Conclusions The alumina supported Pd and Pt based bimetallic catalysts were prepared by modified electroless deposition (ED) method and evaluated for performance for butane dehydrogenation reaction. The bimetallic Pd-Pt catalysts exhibited superior performance in terms of conversion, selectivity, yield and stability compared to that of either Pd or Pt based monometallic catalysts. The superior performance may be attributed to strong synergistic interaction between metals, stronger metal-support interaction and lower acidity of catalysts. The higher activity of alloyed Pd-Pt metal resulted in higher conversion for bimetallic catalysts. The lower acidity resulted in higher butene selectivity and stability for bimetallic catalysts by minimizing the cracking and secondary reactions. The metal deposition order of bimetallic catalysts also affected their performance. The co-deposited catalyst with more uniform distribution of Pd and Pt metals showed better performance than that of bimetallic catalysts prepared by sequential method. The co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed the highest butane conversion of 50 % at 600 °C and maintained a high stability with only 15 % deactivation after reaction time of 10 h. The same catalyst showed highest butene yield (∼42 %). The bimetallic catalyst was also compared with that prepared by conventional impregnation method. The co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst exhibited higher activity and stability in comparison to corresponding co-impregnated bimetallic catalyst due to higher metal dispersion and suppressed coke formation for former. Further, the analysis of spent Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed that physical and electronic structure of the co-deposited bimetallic catalyst was mostly stable with very small modification by reaction condition. The coke deposition was also negligible. coredata.dc:description: The alumina supported Pd-Pt based bimetallic catalysts were prepared by modified electroless deposition and evaluated for butane dehydrogenation. The bimetallic Pd-Pt catalysts exhibited superior performance compared to that of monometallic catalysts. The superior performance may be attributed to strong synergistic interaction between metals, stronger metal-support interaction and lower acidity. The higher activity of alloyed Pd-Pt metal resulted in higher conversion for bimetallic catalysts. The lower acidity resulted in higher butene selectivity and stability for bimetallic catalysts by minimizing cracking and secondary reactions. The co-deposited catalyst with more uniform distribution of Pd and Pt metals showed better performance than bimetallic catalysts prepared by sequential deposition. Co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst showed the highest butane conversion (50 %), butene yield (42 %) and stability. The reported yield is much higher than many reported values for Pt or Pd based catalysts. The co-deposited Pd-Pt/Al catalyst also exhibited better dehydrogenation performance in comparison to corresponding co-impregnated bimetallic catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced performance of supported Pd-Pt bimetallic catalysts prepared by modified electroless deposition for butane dehydrogenation
